data.title: New Metro line between Bahadurgarh and West Delhi opens today
data.meta_description: Travel time between Bahadurgarh and western parts of the city will become easier from Sunday, with the inauguration of the new section of the Green Line.
data.text:
Travel time between Bahadurgarh and western parts of the city will become easier from Sunday, with the inauguration of the new section of the Green Line.

It will now take commuters 50 minutes to travel from Bahadurgarh (City Park) to Mundka, an extension of the Inderlok/Kirti Nagar-Mundka metro line.

The Delhi Metro Rail Corporations on Saturday announced that it will start operations on the Bahadurgarh-Mundka metro corridor from Sunday.

Scheduled to be thrown open for public use from 4 pm on June 24, the corridor, which is an extension of the Inderlok-Mundka metro line - popularly known as the Green Line - will be inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi who will not be physically present to flag off the operations but will be available through video conferencing.

A senior official of the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) however, said Hardeep Singh Puri, minister of housing and urban affairs along with Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar will be present at the City Park metro station to inauguarate the section from Haryana.

The 11.183-km section will now be part of the Green Line. Total length of the stretch will be 29.64 km. The line became operational in two phases between 2010 and 2011. The line will connect the western fringe areas of the national Capital with Bahadurgarh, a growing industrial hub.

Bahadurgarh will be the third town of Haryana to get a metro connectivity after Faridabad and Gurugram.

"Once the line becomes operational, it will provide connectivity to many areas of outer Delhi such as Mundka, Ghevra, Tikri Kalan etc. The Delhi Metro said the metro network will expand to 288 kilometres with 208 metro stations." The section will consist of seven elevated metro stations, four in Delhi- Mundka industrial Area, Ghevra, Tikri Kalan and Tikri Border, while the three stations will be in Haryana- Modern Industrial Estate, Bus Stand, City Park," said Anuj Dayal, executive director, corporate communications, DMRC.

"Initially, 20 trains will be put into service in the entire Inderlok/Kirti Nagar-City Park section. Every alternate train from Mundka will go up to City Park in Bahadurgarh and a frequency of around eight minutes will be maintained between Mundka and City Park. The total running time between Inderlok/Kirti Nagar and City Park (Bahadurgarh) will be about 50 minutes," said Dayal.

Trials on the section were successfully carried out by the Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety on June 1.
